RE: License#: CB820201055
Dear Ms. Coleman:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 3/7/2025. An exit conference was held with your agency on 3/13/2025 . Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
The agency completes annual Department of Health and Human Services
(DHHS) clearances on all its employees. During this inspection, in one of five
employee records reviewed where the employee was employed for over one
year, the record showed the employee's annual DHHS clearance was due by
6/29/2024 but was completed late on 7/19/2024.
Repeat Violation:
Interim Inspection 2024, CAP approved 9/19/2024.
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 4/25/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or

her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Two of five new employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of the employee's probationary
evaluation due by 2/16/2025.
• A second record showed the employee's probationary evaluation which
was due by 8/8/2024 was completed late on 10/22/2024.
Repeat Violation:
Interim Inspection 2024, CAP approved 9/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a
written evaluation of the convictions that addresses the
nature of the conviction, the length of time since the
conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to
regulated activity.
In one of five new employee records reviewed the record did not show a written
statement from the employee related to criminal convictions.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(g) A written statement from the employee regarding
any convictions.
In one of five new employee records reviewed the record did not show a written
evaluation from the agency related to criminal convictions.
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law
(1) An agency shall comply with the child protection
law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.

One of five new employee records reviewed showed the employee's Division of
Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) child protective services history clearance, for
the staff identified as a program support person, which was due prior to the
employee's 5/13/2024 date of hire, was completed late on 11/16/2024.
Repeat Violation:
Renewal Inspection, 2024 CAP approved 9/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household must
have training in and maintain a current certification in
first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the
American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross, or other institution approved by the department.
In one of six open foster home records reviewed the record did not show
documentation of the foster parent’s updated CPR and first aid certification which
was due by 2/1/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
In one of six open foster home records reviewed the record did not show
documentation of an onsite home visit and reevaluation for the foster home which
was due by 2/23/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
Two of six open foster home records reviewed did not show that the agency's
recommendation was submitted within 15 days prior of the foster home's
respective 7/26/2024 and 10/7/2024 licensing expiration date.

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
In one of four special evaluation records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that all workers who had children placed in the home received a
copy of the special evaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to
possible noncompliance with any foster home rule, the
agency must do all the following:
(d) Notify all social service workers who have children
placed in the home that a special evaluation has been
initiated.
In one of four special evaluation records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that all workers who had children placed in the home had been
notified that a special investigation was initiated on the foster home.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
In one of four special evaluation records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that a copy of the report was provided to the foster parent, as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:

(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that the foster
parent has a right to have his or her written response
included as an attachment to the report required by
subrule (5) of this rule.
In one of four special evaluation records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that the foster parent was advised in writing of their right to have a
written response attached to the special evaluation.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home must be notified there
is a corrective action plan and what is required of the
foster parent in that plan.
In one of four special evaluation records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that all workers who had children placed in the home were
advised of the requirements of the foster home's corrective action plan.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of four child closed records reviewed did not show documentation of
subsection (b) as required by the rule. The information was left blank.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.

One of four closed child records reviewed did not show documentation of
subsection (a) as required by the rule. The information was left blank.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by section
5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111.
All the following apply:
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the waiver
is unavailable, then immunizations must begin within 30
calendar days of placement.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's Hepatitis A immunization
was overdue as of 2/1/2025. The child's DTP/DTap/DT/Td/Tdap immunization was
expiring on 3/14/2025, and the agency reported the child's medical examination would
not occur prior to 3/14/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child
placing agency to another child placing agency, a
modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if
no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan must
address why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's 30-day report
which was due by 8/31/2024 was not documented.
Repeat Violation:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 4/25/2023
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster

parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Five of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child's 1/13/2024-4/9/2024 treatment plan was
signed by the youth but not dated; and the child's 7/4/2024-10/1/2024
treatment plan was signed by the caregiver but not dated. I could not
discern whether either treatment plan was signed timely, per the
requirement. Additionally, this child's 4/10/2024-7/3/2024 treatment plan
signatures for the caregiver and youth were not documented.
• A second record did not show documentation that the child's 3/27/2024-
6/24/2024 treatment plan was signed or provided to birth father.
Additionally, the child's 6/25/2024-9/20/2024 treatment plan was not signed
by the birth father until 11/19/2024.
• A third record showed the child's 12/3/2024-12/31/2024 treatment plan was
not signed by the caregiver and birth father until 2/26/2025 and 2/27/2025
respectively.
• A fourth record did not show documentation that the child's 10/1/2024-
1/30/2024 and 10/31/2025-1/27/2025 treatment plan was signed by the
birth father. Nor documentation that the respective treatment plan was
provided to the birth father.
• A fifth record showed the child's 7/5/2024-8/3/2024 treatment plan was not
signed by the birth parent until 9/26/2024. Also, the birth parent’s and
caregiver's signature on the child's 11/1/2024-1/29/2025 treatment plan
was not documented.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance as
required by the rule. The information was either not indicated or was left blank.

Repeat Violation:
Interim Inspection 2024, CAP approved 9/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be
documented in the youth's record.
Two of eight open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of a dental being completed for
the youth after the youth's placement on 8/28/2024 and the last medical
documented in the record on 5/23/2023.
• A second record showed the youth's medical was completed late on
7/18/2024, per the youth's 5/3/2024 date of placement and the last
medical of record on 8/22/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Three of three adoptive evaluations reviewed showed the evaluation was not
completed within 90 days of the family's 6/9/2023, 10/2/2023 and 12/23/2023
respective adopotion application date.
Repeat Violation:
Interim 2024 Inspection, CAP approved 9/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be

recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for
the child or children, visitation/parenting time with the
youth's biological children or a clear explanation why
this is not possible or appropriate.
Two of eight open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record showed the youth's 8/23/2024-11/20/2024 treatment plan was
not signed until 3/2/2025.
• A second record showed the youth's 9/10/2023-12/6/2024 treatment plan
was signed but not dated. I could not discern if this treatment plan was
signed timely, per the requirement.
Repeat Violation:
Interim 2024 Inspection, CAP approved 9/19/2024.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12324(2)(b) Reevaluation:
• The agency was apprised when documenting strengths and weaknesses
of the foster parents in a two-parent family home, it shall clearly and
consistently document the strengths and weaknesses of each parent as
an individual person.
R400.12504(2)(b)(c)(e) Eligibility requirements
• The agency was apprised its assessment documentation shall more
clearly and consistently show assessment proof of (a)(b) and(e) as
described in the rule.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12510(1)(d) Independent living agreement
• The agency was advised having a consistent designated area on the
independent living agreement/contract form where it documents the
youth’s location may aid it in showing consistent compliance with the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD

There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period. This corrective action plan related to its 2024 Interim
inspection where it received 21 rule and policy violations. In this year’s Renewal
inspection, the agency received 22 rule violations. Of these 22 violations 7 are
repeat violations, with 5 being repeat violations from the 2024 Interim inspection.
The agency’s CAP compliance around these 5 rule violations is as follows: the
number of individual cases cited remained the same with respect to 2 citations,
deceased on 2 other violations, and increased on the remaining 1 violation. A
review of the agency’s CAP showed it completed and or implemented all aspects
of its corrective plan, but that implementation did not lend itself to complete
compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s report dated 2/26/2025. The agency
reported the agency has continued to experience workforce issues, around staff
turnover, and most new staff coming with limited or no experience. With staff
being less seasoned the agency reports it has been more challenging for them to
train and have a higher expectation for the field. The chief administrator’s report
indicated the agency also loss a key support person, their health care coordinator,
whom they had hired to aid workers around medicals, dentals and other areas.
Notwithstanding these struggles the agency reported it has continued to train staff
around compliance issues, and allowed staff to continued working hybrid
schedules, all in an effort to offer flexibility to staff, limit stress, and help retain
staff.
The chief administrator’s report further indicated the agency’s corrective action
plan brought about overall positive results. That staff are ultilizing department and
agency resources to assist them. That staff’s increased utilization of outlook
calendars, and the Book of Business has resulted in improved organization, and
awareness for staff to increase rule compliances. Additionally, their corrective
action plan had held supervisors accountable for support to staff around
documentation and task follow up. The agency plans to continue its efforts to
improve rule compliance and to increase staff retention.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2024-2025 annual budget and a copy of its 9/30/2024
Independent financial audit. A review of the documents showed the independent
financial audit indicated the agency entered into an advance payment agreement.
The repayment is to commence 3/30/2025, with quarterly installments of. There
was no concern indicated in the audit related to the agency ability to reimburse

these advances as outlined. Aside from this note in the financial audit report, no
concerns were observed.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the licensee designee, chief administrator, program
manager, and nine supervisory and administrative staff during the entrance
conference, two foster care workers, a licensing worker, independent living worker
and adoption worker were interviewed. Areas of strengths for the agency as
reported by these workers included the agency’s efforts to be inclusive and
diverse; to provide good supervision; and to aid children and families to achieve
goals. Additionally, strengths included there being good agency communication,
strong teams and team work, and the chief administrator’s sincere and genuine
concern for workers. Areas of growth needed included ways to improve staff
retention and minimize staff turnover; possibly obtaining an independent living
home to be able to offer greater independent living potentials to youths; and some
type of coordination and or communication with CWTI (Child Welfare Training
Institute) instructors around shadowing experiences so that new workers do not
miss out on these opportunities when scheduled at the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
No safety issue or concerns were revealed during my onsite visit. The agency has
space and equipment for its staff, and stores files securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert # 1: There were no operable smoke detectors on each level of
occupancy. There was no operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution: The agency reported the foster home has an operable carbon
monoxide/smoke detector on the second floor in the home in the hallway.
Additionally, as of 2/6/2025 the home has smoke detectors on each level of the
home. That all smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are brand new and
in working order. Photos were provided.
Safety Alert #2: There is no operable smoke detector in the basement.
Resolution: The agency provided photos and mentioned a video showing on
2/24/2025 the smoke detector mounted in the basement and in working order.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
